title: Logo, font & Lettering by Leslie Cabarga
content:
Has anyone bought/borrowed and read mr. Cabargas [book](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051029/http:/www.logofontandlettering.com/), and if so, what do you think of it?

comments.content:
Since Leslie used a sample of my lettering in the book, he sent me a copy. I must say I was overwhelmed when I got it. It's loaded with practical information and advice.   
   
The closest thing I've seen was the book on electronic typography and type that Verbum published in the early '90s. I don't have it handy for the actual title (I'm away from my office this week). But Leslie's book is much better in terms of content (and more up-to-date, of course).

I'm reading it at the moment to do a review of it on Speak Up, it will probably happen this weekend. So I'll put a link to it here.   
   
So far I have to say it is very informative, specially for beginner/intermediate level designers (no offense!). It has a lot of great tips, shows by example which is a big plus and is quite humorous. The best part of it is the type tricks for Illustrator, lots of handy, verging-on-the-kitschy-if-applied-wrong type effects.   
   
I'd say it is a very good addition to any type fiend's library.

Same goes for me. A great book with a lot of new ideas and how to realize them. I started drawing again right after having read it.   
   
Servus   
   
Dominik

Hi Fredrik,   
   
I thoroughly enjoyed the book and like Mark am also in it . . .   
   
I think it's the most relevent text on how to actually improve your ability to design by intimately understanding design from a type and lettering perspective. And of course Leslie spells it out very clearly how to do that in Illustrator.   
   
This is perhaps one of a handful of books I've read every word cover to cover in many years.   
   
Plus there is a fantastic section in the back of the book about quoting jobs and the business of design - funny as hell to boot!   
   
Stuart :D   
   
PS: I bought a copy of it before my review copy arrived, so I have an extra if you're interested in buying it from me. Send an e-mail to my address associated with my profile.

If any of you've (somehow) missed the site for this book it's [http://www.logofontandlettering.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051029/http:/www.logofontandlettering.com/)

Hi Leslie,   
   
A question on the FontLab book you're working on - I can't wait for it to come out. Just wondering if you're planning a Windows version ;-)   
   
Seriously, any feedback from FontLab users, who are still mostly using the Windows version, on the illustrations in the book?   
   
Cheers, Si

It's a great book, and I love its irreverent, lighthearted attitude. It's a real change of pace from the much drier books that tend to populate related spaces (though I think there are no books that cover this exact space).   
   
That being said, some of the same qualities that make it great fun seem to make it more of a browse and read-chunks-of book rather than a reference work, for me.   
   
My only very small complaint is that Leslie does readers a bit of a disservice by saying that "glyph" is just the trendy new term for "character." The difference is critical in understanding font-building and text processing for complex languages (e.g. Arabic) and for advanced typography in general (e.g. OpenType, AAT, Graphite, whatever). But that's just one little thing in a generally outstanding book. Guess we'll just have to look ahead to the FontLab book to see glyph vs. character covered better, or I'll have to write my own....   
   
Speaking of the many cool tidbits, I have been using the little blurb about Bezier as my sig quote lately.   
   
Cheers,   
   
T   
   
"Monsieur Bezier, if your thing worked, the Americans would already be using it."   
- Pierre Bezier's boss at Renault, on the discovery of the Bezier curve

\> a visual smorgasbord   
   
More like a visual orgy! :-)   
   
This is one of those rare books that's worth owning even if you never read it! Assuming you're not a Tschichold it'll just make you smile and smile. But then it's full of great reading too! The combination of technique and advice is so rare, I have trouble imagining anybody writing something to upstage it for decades. There are some small spots (dealing with type design specifics) that made me uncomfortable, but I learned so much too - Leslie has stuck gold, and I think it's due to his mature self-confidence that people will like what he likes.   
   
Worth way more than $30, that's for sure.

Tiff: No I wouldn't say you're wrong. You're just using the word "reference" in a different way, is all. For me, Bringhurst's _Elements_ is a reference book, because I use it to look stuff up. But I agree with you and everybody else that Leslie's book is inspirational and likely to incite typographic creativity in most everyone who reads it; it's a sort of touchstone. I'm very glad I bought it.   
   
One thing I forgot to mention was the use of full color throughout. This helps give it a lushness and visual density that just makes it a feast for the eyes.   
   
It's probably in the colophon, but I left the book at home. What's the condensed sans he uses for substantial sections? I found it not entirely to my liking, particularly the oblique (rather than a true italic) seemed a little out of place in such a typographically savvy book. But maybe that's just me.   
   
Cheers,   
   
T

_I'm still uncomfortable with the term so I alternate it with "character." I just can't get myself to refer to a drawing of a letter as a glyph._   
   
Leslie, please do not alternate glyph and character, they are _not_ synonymous terms in digital typography. The distinction of character (semantic encoded text entity) and glyph (conventional representation of character) is extremely important in making sense of the relationship between text processing (input, editing, storage, exchange) and text display (rendering, typographic layout, etc.). If you confuse these two terms, you leave yourself without a meaningful vocabulary for discussing this relationship. The fact that the relationship of character to glyph is not one-to-one makes it particularly important that the distinction is maintained.   
   
You may find my [article](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051029/http:/www.microsoft.com/typography/developers/opentype/default.htm) on OpenType Layout useful in understanding the distinction between and relationship of characters and glyphs.

I think I also covered the glyph/character distinction in the OpenType User Guide, which can be found at [http://www.adobe.com/type/opentype](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051029/http:/www.adobe.com/type/opentype)   
   
I second John's concern. If you aren't comfy with "glyph," I think it would be marginally better to just use "character"; technically incorrect, but not as nearly as problematic as conflating the two concepts.   
   
Cheers,   
   
T

Thanks John and Tom, I've checked out your articles. But I need the definition of glyph   
made way, way simpler. I need an explanation for a 10-year-old, so phrases such as "semantic encoded text entity" are   
problematic for me. Which of the following works for you?:   
1. There were too many nodes on my glyph so it didn't look smooth...   
2. My font has 2007 glyphs in it.   
3. I accidentally pasted the glyph for A into the B window.   
I'm not being facetious. Seems to me that "glyph" is commonly used both to describe a   
letter drawing and a specific slot in a font. Is this right? By the way, who started this word? I just assumed it was the Russians (or the ancient Egytians).   
Leslie

To put it really simply (and not perfectly accurately), A glyph is a letter drawing, and a character is a specific encoding slot. In a font, a given character (slot) has a default glyph (outline) associated with it.   
   
So, all three of those example uses are valid. However, to make the contrast more clear, one might say for #3, "I accidentally pasted the glyph for the character A into the window for the character B."   
   
John's definition is the most correct. But if you want us to simplify (at the risk of losing some accuracy), I'd say: A character is the abstract idea of a letter, like the letter "A." A glyph is a particular version of a letter. So the character "A" in Warnock Pro Italic has a default glyph, but also has at least a couple of alternate glyphs, including a swash form and a small cap. So there's one character, but three glyphs.   
   
Of course, characters actually go beyond letters. Things like numbers or even musical notes or certain symbols can be characters, as long as they have defined encoding slots, and are not simply alternate forms of something else.   
   
It's also worth noting that the relationship between glyphs and characters is _n_-to-_m_, where n and m are integers zero or greater. In plain English, that suggests that several characters may combine to form one glyph (as in a fraction or ligature), and several glyphs may combine to form a single character (as with an accented letter, created on the fly from a letter glyph and an accent glyph).   
   
It gets even more complicated with some other languages. English is the "easy" case. And there's a whole realm of debate on when to encode glyphs as their own characters, but I've spent too much time on that in email with John lately, so I think I won't go there tonight.... ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051029im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
Regards,   
   
T

Leslie, I think the most elegant simplification of "glyph" would be to say that it's "an instance of a character", meaning that it's a given rendering of a letter, numeral, or really any symbol, even stuff that's not encoded. The other terms, like "character", "letter", "symbol" are really abstract concepts, with no inherent physical presence, maybe not even a structural definition\*. That's why really unorthodox glyphs can often be identified as being a certain letter with great certainty.   
   
\* I've come to realize for example that you can never really _show_ the essence of a letter, you can only _describe_ it.

_I'm not being facetious. Seems to me that "glyph" is commonly used both to describe a   
letter drawing and a specific slot in a font. Is this right?_      
   
Yes, because a font is just a big collection of glyphs. Even within a font, and within FontLab, the relationship of a glyph cell to character(s) is not one-to-one: a single glyph can be mapped to multiple characters (this is very common in TrueType font, e.g. the /space/ glyph will be mapped to both the regular space character and the non-breaking space character).   
   
I believe the easiest way to think about the distinction is to accept that 'character' is no longer a typographic term. Glyph is a typographic term that refers to the little images and to their storage in a font. Character is a text encoding term that refers to the abstract identity of, e.g. an uppercase A, that is stored as a number on a computer. The two concepts only come together during display of text, when the characters in the text are mapped to glyphs in a given font.

Depending on the audience could you do away with 'character' alltogether and talk about glyph and something else, say 'code point'?   
   
Si

Late to the party, but Fredrik: the book is great. (The cover is what sucked me in; hee. I got it signed, even!) I don't draw well, but a few pages in and I started up again, anyway.   
   
You'll enjoy the book!

I bought and am reading the book. I think it's delightful and useful. It is full of useful information, a significant amount of which is new to me, and it is done with charm and a light touch.   
   
I particularly appreciate the creative and excellent typography.   
   
You'd think that good typography would be a given in a book about type, but it seems that is often not so. For example, am I the only one who thinks that 'Type & typography' by Baines and Haslam is a typographic disaster?   
   
A typographic comparison - appropriate as both are full of type and lettering illustrations, presenting a similar design challenge.   
   
Both are on bright white coated paper, which of course helps with the illustrations, especially color. Baines & Haslam put all their type on the bright white pages, with a resulting dazzle that detracts from readability. Carbarga softly shades most pages, or uses colored type against white, squelching the dazzle, enhancing readability and adding a pleasant variety.   
   
For text Bains and Haslam use a small size (9 or 10 point) of Swift in a long measure - I count 80 characters - and try to counteract the wide line with large leading - something like 10/14 point. Swift was designed for newspapers, which have narrow columns closely set, and hence is a condensed face with large x-height. Using it totally differently I think flops. The long line with the short extenders is just plain unpleasant to read, especially with the dazzle.   
   
By contrast Cabarga uses the ridiculously easy-to-read Century Schoolbook (I think), whose wide letters match the sometimes wide measure, with an effortly readable result.   
   
The captions and side bars in Bains and Haslam are in Meta, negatively tracked so tight that it is hard to read, for me at least.   
   
The captions and side bars in Carbarga are in narrow columns in a compressed sans (what is it?) which is very readable. It adds fuel to my belief that only narrow sans work well in text. In any case the typeface and the measure and leading are beautifully matched.   
   
Finally, Bains and Haslam have quotations on typography from various luminaries. They are set in a huge, 42 point Meta, with no leading, running across two-page spreads. The text runs continuously, but the two-page spreads are separated by 32 pages. This puts the spreads at the middle of signatures, so the text can align perfectly across the two pages. Clever, but reading the stuff is like putting together a jigsaw puzzle. Also the credits for the quotations jump back to the 10 point Swift, a totally different scale - a violation of Cabarga's rule 20 of the "Immutable laws of Lettering - and the myriad of exceptions thereto."   
   
Overall, the effect in Bains and Haslem is of clever innovation whose result is off-puttingly difficult to read, and visually ungainly.   
   
In Cabarga, I think more consistency from page spread to page spread would make the design stronger, as he uses many different principles to organize his page spreads. This threatens toward the visual chaos, but he manages to keep it undercontrol, perhaps by control of scale from page to page. The bottom line is that every page spread is inviting, readable, and effectively gets across what he wants to explain. To convey such a large amount of technical information in such an agreeable way - both visually and literarily - is an impressive achievement.
